data.title: Railway map distance
data.statement:
On a railway map, the view is often simplified : Lines can only go horizontally, vertically, or diagonally (45°). Between two stations, a line goes diagonally from the first one, until it is aligned (horizontally or vertically) with the second station.
Your program must output the total "straight" (horizontal or vertical) distance, and the total diagonal distance, for a given list of stations.
Diagonal distance between two stations is the minimum difference between the 2 x-coordinates or the 2 y-coordinates.
Straight distance between two stations is the maximum difference between the 2 x-coordinates or the 2 y-coordinates, minus the diagonal distance.
Let's look at an example.
input:
```4
0 0
5 0
9 8
6 8```

Two equivalent maps of the line:
```o----o       o----o
      \           |
       \          |
        \         |
         •        •
         |         \
         |          \
         |           \
      o--o         o--o```

From station 0 to 1: 5 straight distance
From station 1 to 2: 4 straight distance, 4 diagonal distance
From station 2 to 3: 3 straight distance
Total: 12 straight distance, 4 diagonal distance

Output:
```12 4```
data.stubGenerator:
read n:int
loop n read x:int y:int

write 12 4
data.inputDescription:
<<Line 1:>> [[n]], the number of stations
<<[[n]] following lines:>> [[x]] [[y]], 2 space-separated integers, coordinates of a station. Stations are given in the order of the railway line.
data.outputDescription: <<One line:>> [[sdist]] [[ddist]], 2 space-separated integers, respectively "straight" distance, and diagonal distance.

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

On a railway map, the view is often simplified : Lines can only go horizontally, vertically, or diagonally (45°). Between two stations, a line goes diagonally from the first one, until it is aligned (horizontally or vertically) with the second station.
Your program must output the total "straight" (horizontal or vertical) distance, and the total diagonal distance, for a given list of stations.
Diagonal distance between two stations is the minimum difference between the 2 x-coordinates or the 2 y-coordinates.
Straight distance between two stations is the maximum difference between the 2 x-coordinates or the 2 y-coordinates, minus the diagonal distance.
Let's look at an example.
input:
4
0 0
5 0
9 8
6 8


Two equivalent maps of the line:
o----o       o----o
      \           |
       \          |
        \         |
         •        •
         |         \
         |          \
         |           \
      o--o         o--o


From station 0 to 1: 5 straight distance
From station 1 to 2: 4 straight distance, 4 diagonal distance
From station 2 to 3: 3 straight distance
Total: 12 straight distance, 4 diagonal distance

Output:
12 4





   

      
Input

      
Line 1: n, the number of stations
n following lines: x y, 2 space-separated integers, coordinates of a station. Stations are given in the order of the railway line.

   

   

      
Output

      
One line: sdist ddist, 2 space-separated integers, respectively "straight" distance, and diagonal distance.

   

   

      
Constraints

      
2 ≤ n ≤ 10
-200 ≤ x, y ≤ 200

   

   

      
Example

      

         

            
Input

            
4
0 0
5 0
9 8
6 8

         

         

            
Output

            
12 4
